p.s: In my opinion, the speech by Sir David Attenborough is wisely chosen to be held at the COP26 opening.
He directly mentions the urgency and importance of climate change and highlights the responsibility each government has.
Because the problem is, that the United Nations cannot set up laws which help to prevent any further rise in global warming.
The only thing they can do is to agree on a decision and to take it into practice in their homeland.
This is the reason why there is a yearly conference to discuss on how much process has been done.
However, I think that I would be good to state the drastic consequences of climate change in an opening speech, to highlight the importance even more.
The pictures shown at his speech, which I probably pictures of natural diseastersdisasters caused by climate change, are a great way to demonstrate and visualize the effect.
In my opinion, it would be better if Sir David Attenborough would describe the pictures in detail or at least draw a parallel to them.
Therefore the consequences especially in developing countries would play an important role too in the opening speech.
Especially the consequences for developing countries have not been mention enough in the speech, in my opinion.
Personally, I think that this is one of the biggest problems caused by climate change.
Developing countries are mostly affected by it, but at the same time produced the lowest emission.
I do not think this is fair.

I know that there has been an agreement about developed nations paying developing countries a yearly amount to adapt to climate change and reduce their emission, but the amount of money is not enough.
In the speech by Sir David Attenborough he does not mention developing nations as much as needed and does not mention what normal people could do.

I mean, yes it is a climate conference for the governments of each country but if he only adressesaddresses the government who have the responsibility and opportunity to propose laws and change some thing, normal people do not feel adressedaddressed.
This will lead to them not caring about the urgency because they might think my government will know what to do.
But it does depend on what everyone does.
Even small things, like stop using plastic bags or taking the bike will have a huge impact in the future.

Overall, I think that the speech has an impact on the audience attending it at COP26, because they are directly adressesaddressed and the speech underlines the responsibility the importance to implement the decisions in their homeland and to start acting.
However, I do not think that a broader public will feel adressedaddressed by it.
Firstly, because they are not directly adressedaddressed in the speech.
Secondly, because the consequences for developing nations and for everyone or not mentioned enough.
And thirdly, because he mentions that action has to be taken but he is not concrete about what to do.
